revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox video game | title = Battleship | image = Battleship box art.jpg | developer = [[Double Helix Games]] (PS3 & X360)
Magic Pockets (Wii, DS & 3DS) | publisher = [[Activision]] | platforms = [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Wii]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[Nintendo 3DS]] | released = {{Video game release|AU|April 18, 2012|EU|April 20, 2012|NA|May 15, 2012}} | genre = [[First-person shooter]] (X360/PS3)
[[Turn-based strategy]] (Wii/DS/3DS) | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''Battleship''''' is the name of two video games based on the [[Battleship (film)|film]] of the same name (which in turn is based on the board game [[Battleship (game)|Battleship]]), both of them published by [[Activision]] in 2012. The [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] versions are a [[first-person shooter]] developed by [[Double Helix Games]] while the [[Wii]], [[Nintendo DS|DS]] and [[Nintendo 3DS|3DS]] versions are a [[turn-based strategy]] game developed by Magic Pockets. ==Plot== {{Expand section|date=May 2012}} ''Battleship'' follows elite demolitions specialist Cole Mathis as he clashes against an aquatic-based extraterrestrial peril in the sand and sea of the beautiful Hawaiian archipelago. He uses his battle command to command the ships to battle against the alien fleet at sea. The human ships at sea are the Nimitz-class carrier USS Ronald Reagan (CVN-76), Iowa-class battleship USS Missouri (BB-63), fictional Ticonderoga-class cruiser USS Yukon, fictional Arleigh Burke-class destroyer USS John Quincy Adams, fictional Oliver Hazard Perry-class frigate USS Chesapeake, and fictional Virginia-class submarine USS Laredo. The Nintendo versions of the game follows instead the adventures of Capt. Danny Hunter and Lft. Roads and is a [[turn-based strategy]] instead of a [[first-person shooter]]. ==Reception== ===First-person shooter (PlayStation 3 & Xbox 360)=== The [[first-person shooter]] game for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 has received mostly negative reviews. Aggregating review websites [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] gave the Xbox 360 version 40.67% and 38/100{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/xbox360/657787-battleship/index.html|title=Battleship (Xbox 360)|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=2014-03-02}}{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/battleship |title=Battleship for Xbox 360 Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=2014-03-02}} and the PlayStation 3 version 39.43% and 44/100{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps3/657788-battleship/index.html|title=Battleship (PlayStation 3)|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=2014-03-02}}{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/battleship |title=Battleship for PlayStation 3 Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=2014-03-02}} [[PlayStation Official Magazine - UK|PlayStation Official Magazine UK]] remarked "It isn't even the sketchy gameplay that sinks this Battleship – it's the abhorrently commercial objective apparent in every second of rushed gameplay"[http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/review/battleship-ps3-review/ Battleship review], [[PlayStation Official Magazine - UK|PlayStation Official Magazine UK]]. Retrieved March 2, 2014. ===Turn-based strategy (Wii, DS & 3DS)=== Reviews for the [[turn-based strategy]] game for the Wii, DS and 3DS were significantly more positive, but were nonetheless mixed. Aggregating review websites [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] gave the 3DS version 55.83% and 55/100,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/3ds/660034-battleship/index.html|title=Battleship (3DS)|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=2012-11-22}}{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/3ds/battleship |title=Battleship for Nintendo 3DS Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=2012-11-22}} the Wii version 55.50% and 54/100,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/wii/658209-battleship/index.html|title=Battleship (Wii)|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=2012-11-22}}{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii/battleship |title=Battleship for Wii Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=2012-11-22}} and the DS version 40.00%.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ds/658208-battleship/index.html|title=Battleship (DS)|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=2012-11-22}} Nintendo World Report called it "competent", but essentially no more than a second rate variation on [[Advance Wars series|Advance Wars]].Dawson, James (28 May 2012). [http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/review/30316 Wii version review], Nintendo World Report. ''[[Pocket Gamer]]'' gave a more positive review, acknowledging that the game is an Advance Wars copycat but concluding "Those looking to recreate the movie on the go are out of luck here, but if you're after a complex and thoughtful game of naval tactics, ''Battleship'' should be right up your galley."Willington, Peter (14 May 2012). [http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/3DS/Battleship+%283DS%29/review.asp?c=40939 3DS version review], ''[[Pocket Gamer]]''. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.battleshipthevideogame.com}} * {{IMDb title|id=2306461}} {{Portal bar|Video games|2010s}} [[Category:2012 video games]] [[Category:First-person shooters]] [[Category:Naval video games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:Turn-based strategy video games]] [[Category:Video games based on films]] [[Category:Video games developed in France]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Magic Pockets games]] [[Category:Double Helix Games games]]

revision.text:
A '''casino pit''' is an area of a casino which typically contains tables for [[Blackjack]], [[Craps]], [[Roulette]], and other games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bjrnet.com/member/bjapr/P.htm |title=Black Jack Encyclopedia of Casino Twenty-One|accessdate=2007-08-31 }}</ref>
Typically, a pit is organized as two rows of gaming tables arranged back-to-back. The tables face outward toward a public aisleway. The space between the rows is restricted to dealers and other casino personnel. Besides dealers, the pit personnel include game supervisors, still called by their traditional title of "[[floorman]]" (even though many are now women); clerks who man computer terminals where information about players and tables is input; a [[pit manager]] (or "pit boss") who supervises the entire pit; and various other personnel who are in and out of the pit to supply tables with chips, empty money boxes, and perform other maintenance tasks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamingtoday.com/Glossary/casino.cfm |title=General Casino Terminology |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070818231428/http://www.gamingtoday.com/Glossary/casino.cfm |archivedate=2007-08-18 |df= }}</ref> Pits may vary in size, depending on the size of the casino, but are typically eight to twelve blackjack-sized tables or six to eight large craps or roulette tables. At the end of each pit may be nothing more than a barrier keeping the public out, or another game table facing a cross aisle. Small casinos may feature only one pit, while larger resorts in [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]], [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]] or [[Monte Carlo]] may have a dozen or more, with pits devoted to a single game such as craps or roulette.
==Notes== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Casino Pit}} [[Category:Casinos]]

{{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name = Catch Wrestling Association |image = CatchWrestlingAssociation.png |acronym = CWA |established = 1973 |folded=1999 |location = [[Austria]]
[[Germany]] |founder = [[Otto Wanz]] |owner = [[Otto Wanz]] }} The '''Catch Wrestling Association''' (CWA) was a [[professional wrestling]] organization based in [[Austria]] and [[Germany]] that was founded in 1973. It was run by [[Otto Wanz]]. The CWA featured a traditional brand of mat wrestling mixed with various “Strong Man” competitions. The company was engaged in talent-share agreements with other wrestling promotions, including [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] and the [[American Wrestling Association]]. These agreements expanded the opportunities given to many European wrestlers. CWA's biggest card was the [[Euro Catch Festival]], which was held twice a year (it was held in [[Graz]], [[Austria]] in the summer, while in the winter, it was held in [[Bremen]], [[Germany]]). Matches were fought using European rules, including dividing the match into rounds and having the possibility of a victory by [[knockout]]. The CWA World Heavyweight Championship was recognized as the legitimate European World Championship as counterpart to the [[American Wrestling Association|AWA]], [[National Wrestling Alliance|NWA]] and [[WWE|WWF]] titles in North America and [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling|NJPW]]'s [[IWGP Heavyweight Championship]] in Japan. ==Alumni== {{Dynamic list}} {|Johnny South England. |valign="top"| *[[Chris Benoit]]{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/promotions/cwa-germany.html|title=Catch Wrestling Association|accessdate=2008-02-12|publisher=Online World Of Wrestling}} *[[Tony Halme|Ludvig Borga (Tony Halme)]] *[[Robbie Brookside|Robbie Brookside (Robert Brooks)]] *[[Duke Droese|Duke Droese/Marshall Duke (Mike Droese)]] *[[Dave Finlay|Dave "Fit" Finlay]] *[[Tatsumi Fujinami]] *[[John Layfield|John Hawk (John Layfield)]] *[[Ulf Herman|Ulf Herman (Ulf Nadrowski)]] *[[Barry Horowitz]] *[[Don Leo Jonathan|Don Leo Jonathan (Don Heaton)]] *[[Marty Jones]] *[[Owen Hart]] *[[Scott Hall|Texas Scott (Scott Hall)]] *[[Takayuki Iizuka]] *[[Michiyoshi Ohara|Fuji Yamaha (Michiyoshi Ohara)]] |width="40"|  |valign="top"| *[[Carl Ouellet|Jean-Pierre Lafitte/Carl Wallace (Carl Ouellet)]] *[[Chris Jericho|Chris Jericho (Chris Irvine)]] *[[Joe Hitchen|Joe E. revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Time travel video games]] to [[Category:Video games about time travel]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 23]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Chronoton}} {{Infobox video game | title = Chronotron | image = Chronotron-game-main-menu.png | caption = The main menu for Chronotron. | developer = Scarybug Games<ref name="isthmus" /> | publisher = Scarybug Games<ref name="isthmus" /><ref name="chronotroncredits" /> | released = May 2008<ref name="statejournal" /> | genre = [[Puzzle video game|Puzzle]], [[Platform game|Platformer]] | modes = [[Single-player]] | platforms = [[Adobe Flash]]<ref name="xplay" /> | designer = Joe Rheaume<ref name="isthmus" /> | artist = Bogdan Ene<ref name="isthmus" /> | composer = Helge Krabye<ref name="chronotroncredits" /> }}
'''''Chronotron''''' is a [[Flash video|Flash]] [[video game]] developed by Scarybug Games.<ref name="ibabuzz">{{cite web | url = http://www.ibabuzz.com/videogames/2008/07/12/pax-10-five-questions-with-scarybug-games-joe-rheaume/ | title = PAX 10: Five Questions With Scarybug Games' Joe Rheaume | accessdate = 2008-08-29 | date = 2008-07-12 | last = Willis | first = Danny | work = Gamester / [[Contra Costa Times]] | publisher = MediaNews Group | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ibabuzz.com%2Fvideogames%2F2008%2F07%2F12%2Fpax-10-five-questions-with-scarybug-games-joe-rheaume%2F&date=2008-08-29 | archivedate = 2008-08-29 }}</ref> ''Chronotron'' launched on the [[Kongregate]] website in May 2008.<ref name="WSJ">{{cite web | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122291033879496763 | title = Notes From the Underground: Indie Videogames Come of Age | accessdate = 2008-10-02 | date = 2008-10-02 | last = Lawton | first = Christopher | work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | publisher = [[Dow Jones & Company]], Inc. | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fonline.wsj.com%2Farticle%2FSB122291033879496763.html&date=2008-10-03 | archivedate = 2008-10-03 }}</ref> It is notable for having been selected as one of ten games in the PAX 10 2008 out of over eighty entries.<ref name="isthmus" /> It has been described as innovative.<ref name="jayisgames" /> The protagonist is a robot named Chronotron who travels back in time to cooperate with himself.<ref name="xplay"> {{cite video |people = |date = 2008-08-29 |title = The PAX 10: Chronotron |url = http://www.g4tv.com/xplay/videos/28215/The_PAX_10_Chronotron.html |format = embedded Flash video |medium = Television production |publisher = [[G4 Media]], Inc. |location = |accessdate = 2008-08-31 |time = |id = |isbn = |oclc = |quote = }} (Excerpted from the television program [[X-Play]].</ref> The main character must fetch an item before moving to the next room.<ref name="isthmus" /> Solving the puzzles requires sending the main character back in time to coordinate with previous selves.<ref name="isthmus" /> The gameplay requires thinking ahead.<ref name="xplay" /> ''Chronotron'' records the control input, not the protagonist's position.<ref name="pixelsocks" /> As a result, actions by later selves can interfere with earlier selves.<ref name="pixelsocks" /> A number of web sites have licensed ''Chronotron'', including [[Kongregate]] and MTV's [[AddictingGames]].<ref name="pixelsocks" /> It was featured on the front page of Kongregate.<ref name="statejournal" /> The game appears on over 2,000 web sites<ref name="statejournal" /> and has been played more than seven million times.<ref name="statejournal">{{Cite news | last = Alesia | first = Tom | date = 2008-10-26 | title = Madison man has hit with Internet game | periodical = [[Wisconsin State Journal]] | place = [[Madison, Wisconsin]] | publisher = [[Capital Newspapers]] | publication-date = 2008-10-26 | pages = A1 | url = http://www.madison.com/wsj/home/local/311310 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.madison.com%2Fwsj%2Fhome%2Flocal%2F311310&date=2008-10-26 |archivedate = 2008-10-26}} Archived from [http://www.madison.com/wsj/home/local/311310 here] on 2008-10-26.</ref> The developer splits advertising revenue evenly with Kongregate and made more than $1,000 in 2008.<ref name="WSJ" /> The developer had made nearly $15,000 in profits from the game in 2008.<ref name="statejournal" />
==Development== ''Chronotron'' was developed by [[Madison, Wisconsin]] based<ref name="xplay" /> Scarybug Games, which consists of a single person: Joe Rheaume.<ref name="xplay" /><ref name="ibabuzz" /> Rheaume was the sole developer of ''Chronotron''.<ref name="pixelsocks">{{cite web | url = http://www.pixelsocks.com/2008/09/06/interview-with-joe-rheamue-of-chronotron/ | title = Interview with Joe Rheaume of Chronotron | accessdate = 2008-09-08 | date = 2008-09-06 | last = Niese | first = Adam "pixelsocks" | work = PixelSocks | publisher = Adam Niese | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pixelsocks.com%2F2008%2F09%2F06%2Finterview-with-joe-rheamue-of-chronotron%2F&date=2008-09-08 | archivedate = 2008-09-08 }}</ref> Development for ''Chronotron'' took seven months.<ref name="isthmus" /> ''Chronotron'''s sponsorship support was handled through FlashGameLicense.com.<ref name="isthmus" /> Interest in sponsoring ''Chronotron'' allowed Scarybug Games to hire Romanian artist Bogdan Ene to replace the graphics.<ref name="isthmus">{{cite web | url = http://www.isthmus.com/daily/article.php?article=23478 | title = Joe Rheaume's Excellent Adventure: Chronotron goes from Madison to Penny Arcade Expo | accessdate = 2008-08-29 | date = 2008-08-13 | last = Shipley | first = Zac | work = The Daily Page | publisher = Isthmus Publishing Company, Inc. | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.isthmus.com%2Fdaily%2Farticle.php%3Farticle%3D23478&date=2008-08-29 | archivedate = 2008-08-29 }}</ref><ref name="statejournal" /><!--Second cite is for "Romanian" --> Royalty free music was purchased for the game.<ref name="ibabuzz" /> The music's author is Helge Krabye.<ref name="chronotroncredits" /> Sound effects came from the Freesound Project.<ref name="chronotroncredits"> ''Chronotron'' credits screen. {{cite web | url = http://www.kongregate.com/games/Scarybug/chronotron | title = Play Chronotron, a free online game on Kongregate | accessdate = 2008-08-31 | date = 2008-05-06 | publisher = [[Kongregate]] }} </ref>
''Chronotron'''s time travel elements was inspired by advertising for the [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] game ''[[Blinx: The Time Sweeper]]''<ref name="isthmus" /> and an article on ''[[Braid (video game)|Braid]]''.<ref name="isthmus" /><ref name="pixelsocks" /> Rheaume claims to not have played ''Blinx''.<ref name="isthmus" /> ''Chronotron'' was released before the release of ''Braid''.<ref name="rockpapershotgun">{{cite web | url = http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2008/05/08/chronotron/ | title = Chronotron | accessdate = 2008-08-31 | date = 2008-05-08 | last = Meer | first = Alec | work = Rock, Paper, Shotgun | publisher = Rock Paper Shotgun Ltd | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rockpapershotgun.com%2F2008%2F05%2F08%2Fchronotron%2F&date=2008-08-29 | archivedate = 2008-08-29 }}</ref> Rheaume claims to have "thought of the idea of recording input and going back looping on yourself."<ref name="pixelsocks" /> Rheaume wanted there to be no limit on how many times you could travel back in time.<ref name="pixelsocks" /> The game contains references to time travel stories including ''[[Back to the Future]]'', ''[[Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure]]'', and ''[[Doctor Who]]''.<ref name="isthmus" /> The puzzle platformer elements were inspired by ''[[The Lost Vikings]]''.<ref name="isthmus" /> Rheaume notes the similarity between cooperating with your self to the cooperation between the three Vikings in ''The Lost Vikings''.<ref name="pixelsocks" /> Puzzle pacing, with later puzzles building on what is learned earlier, was inspired by ''[[Portal (video game)|Portal]]''.<ref name="isthmus" /> ''Portal'' also inspired the use of humorous signs in game as hints.<ref name="isthmus" />
Rheaume is a Flash developer for his day job.<ref name="xplay" /> Chronotron was built as a hobby.<ref name="xplay" /> As a hobby, Rheaume can develop ideas which don't fit the ideas, time constraints, and budgets of his regular job's client projects.<ref name="xplay" /> Chronotron was developed because Rheaume thought it would be fun to play.<ref name="isthmus" /> Rheaume developed it further because he "thought it really had legs."<ref name="pixelsocks" /> Interest from other people kept Rheaume going.<ref name="pixelsocks" />
The name of the game and the protagonist comes from "chrono" for "time" and "tron" as a generic term for "robot."<ref name="xplay" />
==Reception== The game was selected as one of the ten games for the prestigious PAX 10 in 2008.<ref name="xplay" /> Joe Rheaume was an invited guest to show Chronotron to the [[Penny Arcade Expo]] in 2008 as part of the PAX 10.<ref name="isthmus" /> ''Chronotron'' was selected as one of ten games from over eighty submitted.<ref name="isthmus" /> ''Chronotron'' is the only browser-based Flash game in the PAX 10 2008.<ref name="xplay" />
''Chronotron'' has been described as "a very deep, complex game involving time travel and past selves."<ref name="ibabuzz" /> Game designer [[Greg Costikyan]] described ''Chronotron'' as "a simple, satisfying, and enjoyable exploration of the effects of one novel mechanic on a well-established form."<ref name="playthisthing"> {{cite web | url = http://playthisthing.com/chronotron | title = Chronotron: Platform Puzzler with Time Travel | accessdate = 2008-08-29 | date = 2008-07-18 | last = Costikyan | first = Greg |author2=costik | authorlink = Greg Costikyan | work = Play This Thing! | publisher = [[Manifesto Games]], Inc. | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fplaythisthing.com%2Fchronotron&date=2008-08-29 | archivedate = 2008-08-28 }} </ref> A review on [[Jay Is Games]] described ''Chronotron'' as "a platform puzzler with a really innovative (and addictive) twist." <ref name="jayisgames">{{cite web | url = http://jayisgames.com/archives/2008/05/chronotron.php | title = Chronotron | accessdate = 2008-08-31 | date = 2008-05-08 | author = Josh | work = CasualGameplay/[[Jay Is Games]] | publisher = [[Jay Is Games]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fjayisgames.com%2Farchives%2F2008%2F05%2Fchronotron.php&date=2008-08-29 | archivedate = 2008-08-29 }}</ref> The same review said of the "rewind mechanic", "the concept is refined—and executed almost to perfection."<ref name="jayisgames" /> A reviewer on ''Rock, Paper, Shotgun'' said "Certainly I feel worn out after wrapping my head around a few levels, but also satisfied and pleased — you really should go play this."<ref name="rockpapershotgun" /> [[Kotaku]] called it "a hell of a fun flash game."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://kotaku.com/5020536/back-to-the-present-with-chronotron | title = Back to the Present with Chronotron | accessdate = 2008-09-08 | date = 2008-06-28 | last = Good | first = Owen | work = [[Kotaku]] | publisher = [[Gawker Media]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fkotaku.com%2F5020536%2Fback-to-the-present-with-chronotron&date=2008-09-09 | archivedate = 2008-09-09 }}</ref> [[Gawker.com]] rated ''Chronotron'' "Pretty pretty good" and said "If you loved Portal, you'll like this enough for two lunch breaks."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gawker.com/389371/chronotron | title = Lunchtime Flash Game: Chronotron | accessdate = 2008-09-08 | date = 2008-05-12 | last = Douglas | first = Nick | work = [[Gawker.com]] | publisher = [[Gawker Media]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fgawker.com%2F389371%2Fchronotron&date=2008-09-09 | archivedate = 2008-09-09 }}</ref> Jamie Fristrom of Torpex Games, a fellow honoree at the PAX 10, said, "Chronotron is actually my favorite of the PAX 10."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamedevblog.com/2008/09/notes-on-pax.html | title = Notes on PAX and the PAX 10 | accessdate = 2008-09-08 | date = 2008-09-01 | last = Fristrom | first = Jamie | work = GameDevBlog | publisher = Jamie Fristrom | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gamedevblog.com%2F2008%2F09%2Fnotes-on-pax.html&date=2008-09-09 | archivedate = 2008-09-09 }}</ref> A GameCyte author "wholeheartedly recommend[ed] Chronotron to any and all puzzle fans." <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamecyte.com/2008/05/08/chronotrons-time-traveling-puzzles-are-made-of-win/1200 | title = Chronotron's Time-Traveling Puzzles are Made Of Win | accessdate = 2008-09-08 | date = 2008-05-08 | last = Hollister | first = Sean | work = GameCyte | publisher = GameCyte / Panteon Labs, LLC | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gamecyte.com%2F2008%2F05%2F08%2Fchronotrons-time-traveling-puzzles-are-made-of-win%2F1200&date=2008-09-09 | archivedate = 2008-09-09 }}</ref> Hecklerspray described ''Chronotron'' as "incredible" and "so impressively playable that it'll probably kill your productivity for the day stone dead."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.hecklerspray.com/slackerjack-chronotron/200814186.php | title = SLACKERJACK - Chronotron | accessdate = 2008-09-08 | date = 2008-05-16 | last = Heritage | first = Stuart | work = Hecklerspray | publisher = Hecklerspray | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hecklerspray.com%2Fslackerjack-chronotron%2F200814186.php&date=2008-09-09 | archivedate = 2008-09-09 }}</ref>
The developer believes the "biggest" and "fairest criticism" are problems with synchronizing robots' actions between time loops.<ref name="ibabuzz" />
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.scarybuggames.com/2008/05/chronotron/ Chronotron] on Scarybug Games ([http://www.scarybuggames.com/chronotron.swf download]) * [http://www.kongregate.com/games/scarybug/chronotron Chronotron] with bonus levels on [[Kongregate]] ([http://chat.kongregate.com/gamez/0001/0359/live/chronotron.swf download]) * [http://www.scarybuggames.com/ Scarybug Games]

revision.text:
{{Infobox album | name = Disclaimer II | type = studio | artist = [[Seether]] | cover = SeetherDisclaimerIIAlbumCover.jpg | alt = | released = 15 June 2004 | recorded = 2002–04 | venue = | studio = | genre = {{hlist|[[Post-grunge]]|[[alternative metal]]|[[nu metal]]http://www.heavyblogisheavy.com/2016/05/09/in-defense-of-nu-metal/}} | length = 72:57 | label = [[Wind-up Records|Wind-up]] | producer = {{hlist|[[Jay Baumgardner]]|[[Bob Marlette]]}} | prev_title = [[Disclaimer (Seether album)|Disclaimer]] | prev_year = 2002 | next_title = [[Karma and Effect]] | next_year = 2005 | misc = {{Singles | name = Disclaimer II | type = studio | single1 = [[Broken (Seether song)|Broken]] | single1date = 13 April 2004 }} }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[AllMusic]] | rev1score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/disclaimer-ii-r695170|title=Disclaimer II – Seether|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|first=Johnny|last=Loftus|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405125825/http://www.allmusic.com/album/disclaimer-ii-r695170|archivedate=2011-04-05|deadurl=yes}} | rev2 = [[Ultimate Guitar Archive]] | rev2score = {{Rating|10|10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/reviews/compact_discs/seether/disclaimer_ii/index.html|title=Disclaimer II Review|publisher=[[Ultimate Guitar Archive]]}} }} '''''Disclaimer II''''' is the second album released by the South African [[Rock music|rock]] band [[Seether]]. This disc is a recompilation of the band's first album, ''[[Disclaimer (Seether album)|Disclaimer]]'', from 2002. Although the 12 tracks from the original album are present, they have been slightly remixed and differ from the original. Also, the majority of the remixed tracks feature additional lead guitar melodies with the addition of a permanent lead guitarist to the band's line-up prior to the release of the album. This is also the first Seether album to feature contributions from their current drummer John Humphrey. In [[Europe]], the album includes four tracks more than its predecessor; in the [[United States]], the album has eight extra tracks, some of which had been previously released on soundtracks, such as "Hang On," which had been featured on the 2003 [[Daredevil: The Album|''Daredevil'' soundtrack]] and "Out of My Way," which had been featured on the soundtrack to the 2003 [[horror film]] ''[[Freddy vs. Jason]]''. "Fine Again" also appeared on ''[[Madden NFL 2003]]'' and ''[[1080° Avalanche]]''. A primary reason for the reworking of ''Disclaimer'' was the popularity of "[[Broken (Seether song)|Broken]]." Originally a simple acoustic ballad, it was remade into an electric, duet version with vocals by [[Amy Lee]]. This new version was originally featured on the 2004 [[The Punisher: The Album|''Punisher'' soundtrack]] and had an accompanying [[music video]]. Both the US and European releases include the new rendition of "Broken," and ''Disclaimer II'' subsequently became Seether's most successful album commercially. The song "Sold Me" was used for [[WWE]]'s [[Bad Blood (2004)|Bad Blood]] pay per view, along with WWE also using "Out of My Way" as the entrance theme of [[Zach Gowen]]. The song "Take Me Away" is an acoustic version of a track from their first independent album (originally as Saron Gas), ''Fragile'' (2000). == Background == The idea of releasing Disclaimer II was a record label decision. [[Shaun Morgan]] didn't want include the new version of [[Broken (Seether song)|Broken]] with [[Amy Lee]] on the first album, because he thought the first album was finished. Eventually the band and the label came to a compromise; they recorded extra tracks for the album, as they wanted to include it as a bonus CD. Instead, the label discontinued the first barcode on the first album and they had to add the new version of Broken, as it was part of the deal.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DPJ5tDclwBQ "THE STORY OF SEETHER | (2002-2017)"] == Track listing == All songs written by [[Shaun Morgan]] and [[Dale Stewart]]. {{Tracklist | total_length = | title1 = [[Gasoline (Seether song)|Gasoline]] | length1 = 2:49 | title2 = 69 Tea | length2 = 3:31 | title3 = [[Fine Again]] | length3 = 4:04 | title4 = Needles | length4 = 3:26 | title5 = [[Driven Under]] | length5 = 4:34 | title6 = Pride | length6 = 4:07 | title7 = Sympathetic | length7 = 4:10 | title8 = Your Bore | length8 = 3:58 | title9 = Fade Away | length9 = 3:53 | title10 = Pig | length10 = 3:29 | title11 = Fuck It | length11 = 2:58 | title12 = Broken | length12 = 4:18 | title13 = Sold Me | length13 = 3:41 | title14 = Got It Made | length14 = 5:10 | title15 = Cigarettes | length15 = 3:11 | title16 = [[Broken (Seether song)|Broken]] | length16 = 4:18 | title17 = | length17 = | title18 = | length18 = | title19 = | length19 = | title20 = | length20 = |all_writing=|note16=featuring [[Amy Lee]]|headline=Standard Version[https://www.discogs.com/Seether-Disclaimer-II/release/383779 "Seether - Disclaimer II, Discogs"]}}{{Track listing | all_writing = | collapsed = yes | headline = Deluxe Version[https://www.discogs.com/Seether-Disclaimer-II/release/1684942 "Seether - Disclaimer II [Deluxe], Discogs"] | title1 = | length1 = | title2 = | length2 = | title3 = | length3 = | title4 = | length4 = | title5 = | length5 = | title6 = | length6 = | title7 = | length7 = | title8 = | length8 = | title9 = | length9 = | title10 = | length10 = | title11 = | length11 = | title12 = | length12 = | title13 = | length13 = | title14 = Cigarettes | length14 = 3:11 | title15 = Love Her | length15 = 4:12 | title16 = Take Me Away | length16 = 3:56 | title17 = Got It Made | length17 = 5:10 | title18 = Out of My Way | length18 = 3:52 | title19 = Hang On | length19 = 3:11 | title20 = [[Broken (Seether song)|Broken]] | note20 = featuring [[Amy Lee]] | length20 = 4:18 | total_length = 72:57 }} *Tracks 1 – 12 are the same as on the original Disclaimer album, although slightly reworked. Tracks 13 – 20 did not appear on the original Disclaimer album. ==Personnel== ===Seether=== *[[Shaun Morgan]] – lead vocals and rhythm guitar *[[Pat Callahan]] – lead guitar *[[Dale Stewart]] – bass guitar and backing vocals ===Additional personnel=== *[[Josh Freese]] – drums on tracks 1 to 12 *[[Dave Cohoe]] – drums on "Out of My Way" *[[Nick Oshiro]] – drums on "Hang On" *[[John Humphrey (musician)|John Humphrey]] – drums on other album tracks *[[Amy Lee]]- guest vocals on "Broken" ==Chart positions== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Chart (2004) !Peak

revision.text:
[[Image:Dramatenselevskola1922.jpg|thumb|right|360px|'''Dramatens elevskola - Class 1922–24.''' From left: Lena Cederqvist, Karl-Magnus Thulstrup, Mona Mårtensson, [[Mimi Pollak]], [[Vera Schmiterlöw]], [[Greta Garbo]], [[Alf Sjöberg]] and [[Håkan Westergren]]]] [[Image:Sara Torsslow-1847.jpg|thumb|[[Sara Torsslow]], one of the stars of the 19th-century, who was educated at Dramatens elevskola.]] '''Kungliga Dramatiska Teaterns Elevskola''' ([[Swedish language|Swedish]] for "The Royal Dramatic Theatre's acting school"), also known as '''Dramatens elevskola''', was the acting school of [[Sweden]]'s national stage, [[Royal Dramatic Theatre|The Royal Dramatic Theatre]], and for many years (1787–1964) seen as the foremost theatre school and drama education for Swedish stage actors. It was established in 1787 by the theatre and art loving King [[Gustav III of Sweden|Gustav III]] and was for many years under the protection of the [[Swedish Royal Family|Swedish royal family]].
==History== The school was founded in 1787. Previously, actors had been educated as personal students of individual actors at the theatre, but it was decided that a school was necessary for a more secure succession of the profession and to teach children in the profession from the start from examples made by the continent. In 1788, it was called The Children's Theatre, teaching children between the ages of 9-14{{Citation needed|date=February 2014}}. The school is noted to have performed a play for the king and the royal court. One of the first students known was [[Lars Hjortsberg]], who also performed at this occasion and became one of the stars of Swedish theatre history. The school was re-organised in 1793 by [[Anne Marie Milan Desguillons]] and her spouse, two actors from the French Theatre in [[Bollhuset]] in Stockholm. The students was often used in small parts by the royal theatre and in student performances. The instructors were often actors from the royal theatre.
The quality of the drama school was considered to be one of [[Europe]]'s greatest (equivalent to British [[RADA]]) {{Citation needed|date=February 2014}} and up until 1964 it still featured traditional [[fencing]], [[ballet]]-training, plastik (''plastique''; body movement and posture on stage), [[recital]]- and [[voice]]-training (following the same instructions since 1819) and teachings of skilled masking techniques - everything much the same since the 18th Century. The education originally was one year long, but later in the end of the 1910s became two years and later in 1930s extended to three years (as a third year as practising actor at the national stage in its productions was included and compulsory for all).
In the 1960s, Sweden - as many other countries - was influenced by new theatre traditions; such as [[method acting]] and new international thoughts on drama education. The International Theatre Institute arranged several symposia in Europe, which both students and teachers attended and the debate grew. This was also the 1960s and in the early days of the great emerging liberation movement through the world and soon with student revolts all over Europe; it was a time of change in the world of arts and culture, as well as in society in general and in the political debate. The opinion in Sweden was strong to make the acting school a national, non-traditional, independent theatre school governed by the state. The old education and teaching methods were questioned, and it was soon decided by the Swedish government that the school was to be separated from the Royal Dramatic Theatre (aka Dramaten) and become independent.
It was the then-managing director of the Royal Dramatic Theatre, [[Ingmar Bergman]], who in 1964 initiated the final decision of separation (mostly because he was frustrated that the increasing number of students required more room and deserved more attention than he felt Dramaten could upbring at the time). However, he later came to regret this decision, bitterly calling it (in a late 1990s interview) "the most stupid thing I've done in my entire life" as he later felt that the long inherited theatre tradition was completely lost within the Dramaten building.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} For better or worse can always be debated (what tools and training methods make good actors?); but it's a fact that the students lost contact with the Royal Dramatic Theatre's long tradition, drama history and practising actors (who also regularly had taught at the acting school what other actors/directors once had taught them; and others before them).{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} Looking back, many in Sweden now believe that the 1964 separation definitely affected negatively on the quality of theatre training and acting education in the country; a tradition was lost after 1964 and today many feel that the later national drama educational forms just couldn't quite reach the former standards that the Royal Dramatic Theatre's former acting school presented.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}}
The last class of Dramatens elevskola was the class of 1967 (whose students enrolled in 1964 and graduated three years later).
==Famous students== Famous students at Dramatens elevskola include: [[Signe Hasso]], [[Greta Garbo]], [[Gunnar Björnstrand]], [[Ingrid Bergman]], [[Max von Sydow]], [[Stellan Skarsgård]], [[Jan Malmsjö]], [[Nils Asther]], [[Gunn Wållgren]], [[Inga Tidblad]], [[Börje Ahlstedt]], [[Bibi Andersson]], [[Eva Dahlbeck]], [[Ingrid Thulin]], [[Stig Järrel]], [[Gerda Lundequist]] and [[Lars Hanson]], a.o (including most of the later so called "[[Ingmar Bergman]]-actors").
==Notable teachers== ===18th and 19th century===
* [[Hanna Brooman]] * [[Charlotta Eriksson]] * [[Julie Alix de la Fay]] * [[Johann Christian Friedrich Hæffner]] * [[Signe Hebbe]] * [[Carolina Kuhlman]] * [[Bertha Tammelin]]
===20th century=== *[[Hilda Borgström]] *[[Gabriel Alw]] *[[Renée Björling]] *[[Gerda Lundequist]] *[[Hjördis Petterson]] *[[Ingrid Luterkort]] *[[Lisa Steier]]
==Principals== ===18th and 19th century=== * 1790–1793 Francois Marie Moussé Félix * 1793–1800 Joseph Sauze Desguillons * 1793–1800 [[Anne Marie Milan Desguillons]] ''(jointly with husband)'' * 1804–1812 [[Sofia Lovisa Gråå]] * 1812–1815 [[Caroline Halle-Müller]] * 1819–1823 [[Maria Franck]] ''(also called Kristina Ruckhman)'' * 1828–1831 [[Gustav Åbergsson]] * 1831–1834 [[Karolina Bock]] ''(first time)'' * 1834–1840 [[Nils Almlöf]] * 1840–1841 V. Svensson ''(first time)'' * 1841–1856 [[Karolina Bock]] ''(second time)'' * 1856–1857 V. Svensson ''(second time)'' * 1857–1868 J. Jolin * 1868–1874 Frans T. Hedberg * 1874–1877 [[Knut Almlöf]] * 1874–1877 [[Betty Deland|Betty Almlöf]] ''(jointly with husband)'' * 1877–1886 A. Willman * 1877–1886 [[Hedvig Willman]] ''(jointly with husband'') * 1889–1890 E. Hillberg * 1892–1898 N. Personne * 1898–1904 A. Örtengren
===20th century=== * 1948–1953 [[Olle Hilding]]
==See also== * [[Bollhuset]]
==Further information== For further information on national Swedish drama education, present and historically, ''see'': *[[Swedish National Academy of Mime and Acting|National Academy of Mime and Acting]] (NAMA).
==Sources and references== *''Om igen, herr Molander!'' by Ingrid Luterkort, Stockholmia Förlag, Borås, Sweden, 1998. * Gidlunds förlag : ''Ny svensk teaterhistoria. Teater före 1800'' * Sten Carlsson: ''Den svenska historien: Gustav III, en upplyst envåldshärskare. Band 10'' (The Swedish history: Gustav III, an enlightened despot)
==External links== * [http://www.dramaten.se/ The Royal Dramatic Theatre - DRAMATEN.se] {{swe icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070428034304/http://www.beepworld.de/members12/garbofan2/garbo_at_dramaten.htm Greta Garbo at Dramaten]

revision.text:
{{About|the feeling|other uses|Epiphany (disambiguation){{!}}Epiphany}}
An '''epiphany''' (from the [[ancient Greek]] ἐπιφάνεια, ''epiphaneia'', "manifestation, striking appearance") is an experience of a sudden and striking realization. Generally the term is used to describe scientific breakthrough, religious or philosophical discoveries, but it can apply in any situation in which an enlightening realization allows a problem or situation to be understood from a new and deeper perspective. Epiphanies are studied by [[psychologist]]s<ref name="Jarvis1996"/><ref name="McDonald2008"/> and other scholars, particularly those attempting to study the process of [[innovation]].<ref name="Berkun2010-4"/><ref name="Berkun2010-10"/><ref name="LeemingMadden2009"/>
Epiphanies are relatively rare occurrences and generally follow a process of significant thought about a problem. Often they are triggered by a new and key piece of information, but importantly, a depth of prior knowledge is required to allow the leap of understanding.<ref name="Berkun2010-4"/><ref name="Berkun2010-10"/><ref name="Kawasaki2008"/><ref name="Berkun2010-13"/> Famous epiphanies include [[Archimedes]]'s discovery of a method to determine the density of an object ("[[Eureka (word)|Eureka]]!") and [[Isaac Newton]]'s realization that a falling apple and the orbiting moon are both pulled by the same force.<ref name="Kawasaki2008"/><ref name="Berkun2010-13"/><ref name="Tigges1999"/>
==History== The word epiphany originally referred to insight through the [[divine]].<ref name="Berkun2010-5"/><ref>Platt, V. J. (2011) ''Facing the Gods. Epiphany and Representation in Graeco-Roman Art, Literature and Religion''. Cambridge University Press.'' ''</ref> Today, this concept is more often used without such connotations, but a popular implication remains that the epiphany is [[supernatural]], as the discovery seems to come suddenly from the outside.<ref name="Berkun2010-5"/>
The word's secular usage may owe much of its popularity to Irish novelist [[James Joyce]]. The Joycean epiphany has been defined as "a sudden spiritual manifestation, whether from some object, scene, event, or memorable phase of the mind — the manifestation being out of proportion to the significance or strictly logical relevance of whatever produces it."<ref>Morris Beja, ''Epiphany in the Modern Novel.'' Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1971. P. 18.</ref> The author used epiphany as a literary device within each entry of his short story collection ''[[Dubliners]]'' (1914); his protagonists came to sudden recognitions that changed their view of themselves and/or their social conditions. Joyce had first expounded on epiphany's meaning in the fragment ''[[Stephen Hero]],'' although this was only published posthumously in 1944. For the philosopher [[Emmanuel Lévinas]], epiphany or a manifestation of the divine is seen in another's face (see [[Face-to-face (philosophy)|face-to-face]]). [[Image:Flammarion.jpg|thumb|right|[[Flammarion engraving]]. From "L'atmosphère", book of 1888]] In traditional and pre-modern cultures, [[initiation]] rites and [[western esotericism|mystery religion]]s have served as vehicles of epiphany, as well as the arts. The [[Greek drama]]tists and [[Greek poetry|poets]] would, in the ideal, induct the audience into states of ''[[catharsis]]'' or ''[[kenosis]]'', respectively. In modern times an epiphany lies behind the title of [[William Burroughs]]' ''[[Naked Lunch]]'', a drug-influenced state, as Burroughs explained, "a frozen moment when everyone sees what is at the end of the fork." Both the [[Dadaist]] [[Marcel Duchamp]] and the [[Pop Art]]ist [[Andy Warhol]] would invert expectations by presenting commonplace objects or graphics as works of [[fine art]] (for example a [[Fountain (Duchamp)|urinal as a fountain]]), simply by presenting them in a way no one had thought to do before; the result was intended to induce an epiphany of "what art is" or is not.
==Process== Epiphanies can come in many different forms, and are often generated by a complex combination of experience, memory, knowledge, predisposition and context. A contemporary example of an epiphany in education might involve the process by which a student arrives at some form of new insight or clarifying thought.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kounios|first1=John|last2=Beeman|first2=Mark|title=The Aha! Moment: The Cognitive Neuroscience of Insight|journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science|date=August 2009|volume=18|issue=4|pages=210–216|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8721.2009.01638.x|citeseerx=10.1.1.521.6014}}</ref> Despite this popular image, epiphany is the result of significant work on the part of the discoverer, and is only the satisfying result of a long process.<ref name="Berkun2010-6-8"/> The surprising and fulfilling feeling of epiphany is so surprising because one cannot predict when one's labor will bear fruit, and our subconscious can play a significant part in delivering the solution; and is fulfilling because it is a reward for a long period of effort.<ref name="Berkun2010-10"/><ref name="Berkun2010-6-8"/>
==Myth== A common myth predicts that most, if not all, innovations occur through epiphanies.<ref name="Kawasaki2008"/> Not all innovations occur through epiphanies; Scott Berkun notes that "the most useful way to think of an epiphany is as an occasional bonus of working on tough problems".<ref name="Berkun2010-13"/> Most innovations occur without epiphany, and epiphanies often contribute little towards finding the next one.<ref name="Berkun2010-13"/> Crucially, epiphany cannot be predicted, or controlled.<ref name="Berkun2010-13"/>
Although epiphanies are only a rare occurrence, crowning a process of significant labor, there is a common myth that epiphanies of sudden comprehension are commonly responsible for leaps in technology and the sciences.<ref name="Kawasaki2008"/><ref name="Berkun2010-13"/> Famous epiphanies include Archimedes' realization of how to estimate the volume of a given mass, which inspired him to shout "[[Eureka (word)|Eureka]]!" ("I have found it!").<ref name="Berkun2010-4"/> The biographies of many mathematicians and scientists include an epiphanic episode early in the career, the ramifications of which were worked out in detail over the following years. For example, allegedly [[Albert Einstein]] was struck as a young child by being given a compass, and realizing that some unseen force in space was making it move. Another, perhaps better, example from Einstein's life occurred in 1905 after he had spent an evening unsuccessfully trying to reconcile Newtonian physics and Maxwell's equations. While taking a streetcar home, he looked behind him at the receding clocktower in [[Bern]] and realized that if the car sped up close to the speed of light, he would see the clock slow down; with this thought, he later remarked, "a storm broke loose in my mind," which would allow him to understand special relativity. Einstein had a second epiphany two years later in 1907 which he called "the happiest thought of my life" when he imagined an elevator falling, and realized that a passenger would not be able to tell the difference between the weightlessness of falling, and the weightlessness of space - a thought which allowed him to generalize his theory of relativity to include gravity as a curvature in spacetime. A similar flash of [[holistic]] understanding in a prepared mind was said to give [[Charles Darwin]] his "hunch" (about [[natural selection]]), and Darwin later stated that he always remembered the spot in the road where his carriage was when the epiphany struck. Another famous epiphany myth is associated with Isaac Newton's apple story,<ref name="Berkun2010-10"/> and yet another with Nikola Tesla's discovery of a workable alternating current induction motor. Though such epiphanies might have occurred, they were almost certainly the result of long and intensive periods of study those individuals had undertaken, rather than an out-of-the-blue flash of inspiration about an issue they had not thought about previously.<ref name="Kawasaki2008"/><ref name="Berkun2010-13"/>
Another myth is that epiphany is simply another word for (usually spiritual) [[Vision (spirituality)|vision]]. Actually, realism and psychology make epiphany a different mode as distinguished from vision, even though both vision and epiphany are often triggered by (sometimes seemingly) irrelevant incidents or objects.<ref name="Tigges1999"/><ref name="Berkun2010-11"/>
==In religion== {{Further information|Epiphany (holiday)|theophany|hierophany}} In Christianity, the Epiphany refers to a realization that Christ is the Son of God. Western churches generally celebrate the [[Visit of the Magi]] as the [[revelation]] of the [[Incarnation (Christianity)|Incarnation]] of the infant Christ, and commemorate the [[Epiphany (holiday)|Feast of the Epiphany]] on January 6. Traditionally, Eastern churches, following the Julian rather than the Gregorian calendar, have celebrated Epiphany (or [[Theophany]]) in conjunction with Christ's baptism by [[John the Baptist]] and celebrated it on January 19; however, other Eastern churches have adopted the Western Calendar and celebrate it on January 6.<ref name="The Season of Epiphany"/> Some Protestant churches often celebrate Epiphany as a season, extending from the last day of Christmas until either [[Ash Wednesday]], or the Feast of the Presentation on February 2.
In more general terms, the phrase "religious epiphany" is used when a person realizes their faith, or when they are convinced that an event or happening was really caused by a deity or being of their faith. In Hinduism, for example, epiphany might refer to [[Arjuna]]'s realization that [[Krishna]] (incarnation of God serving as his charioteer in the "[[Bhagavad Gita]]") is indeed representing the Universe. The Hindu term for epiphany would be [[bodhodaya]], from Sanskrit [[bodha]] 'wisdom' and udaya 'rising'. Or in Buddhism, the term might refer to the Buddha obtaining enlightenment under the [[bodhi]] tree, finally realizing the nature of the universe, and thus attaining [[Nirvana]]. The Zen term ''[[kensho]]'' also describes this moment, referring to the feeling attendant on realizing the answer to a ''[[koan]]''.
==See also== * [[Anagnorisis]] * [[Eureka effect]] * [[Hierophany]] * [[Lateral thinking]] * [[Peripeteia]] * [[Satori]] * [[Theophany]] * [[Apophenia]]
==References== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name="Berkun2010-10">{{cite book|author=Scott Berkun|title=The Myths of Innovation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPCgnc70MSgC&pg=PA10|accessdate=15 October 2011|date=27 August 2010|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4493-8962-8|pages=10–11}}</ref>
<ref name="Berkun2010-11">{{cite book|author=Scott Berkun|title=The Myths of Innovation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPCgnc70MSgC&pg=PA11|accessdate=15 October 2011|date=27 August 2010|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4493-8962-8|pages=11–12}}</ref>
<ref name="Berkun2010-13">{{cite book|author=Scott Berkun|title=The Myths of Innovation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPCgnc70MSgC&pg=PA13|accessdate=15 October 2011|date=27 August 2010|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4493-8962-8|pages=13–15}}</ref>
<ref name="Berkun2010-4">{{cite book|author=Scott Berkun|title=The Myths of Innovation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPCgnc70MSgC&pg=PA4|accessdate=15 October 2011|date=27 August 2010|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4493-8962-8|page=4}}</ref>
<ref name="Berkun2010-5">{{cite book|author=Scott Berkun|title=The Myths of Innovation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPCgnc70MSgC&pg=PA5|accessdate=15 October 2011|date=27 August 2010|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4493-8962-8|page=5}}</ref>
<ref name="Berkun2010-6-8">{{cite book|author=Scott Berkun|title=The Myths of Innovation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPCgnc70MSgC&pg=PA6|accessdate=15 October 2011|date=27 August 2010|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4493-8962-8|pages=6–8}}</ref>
<ref name="Jarvis1996">{{cite book|author=Arianna Jarvis|title=Taking a break: Preliminary investigations into the psychology of epiphanies as discontinuous change experiences|url=http://scholarworks.umass.edu/dissertations/AAI9709611|accessdate=19 September 2012|year=1996|publisher=University of Massachusetts-Amherst}}</ref>
<ref name="Kawasaki2008">{{cite book|author=Guy Kawasaki|title=Reality check: the irreverent guide to outsmarting, outmanaging, and outmarketing your competition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VE2CMTHnZZYC&pg=PA125|accessdate=16 October 2011|date=1 December 2008|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-1-59184-223-1|page=125}}</ref>
<ref name="LeemingMadden2009">{{cite book|author1=David Adams Leeming|author2=Kathryn Madden|author3=Stanton Marlan|title=Encyclopedia of psychology and religion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g0QQtlJSyOEC&pg=PA287|accessdate=16 October 2011|date=September 2009|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-0-387-71801-9|page=287}}</ref>
<ref name="McDonald2008">{{cite journal|last=McDonald|first=Matthew|title=The Nature of Epiphanic Experience|journal=Journal of Humanistic Psychology|year=2008|volume=48|issue=1|pages=89–115|doi=10.1177/0022167807311878|url=http://jhp.sagepub.com/content/48/1/89|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref>
<ref name="The Season of Epiphany">{{cite web|url=http://www.crivoice.org/cyepiph.html |title=The Season of Epiphany |publisher=Crivoice.org |date=2011-10-11 |accessdate=2011-10-16}}</ref>
<ref name="Tigges1999">{{cite book|author=Wim Tigges|title=Moments of moment: aspects of the literary epiphany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zK4U0gYO10oC&pg=PA43|accessdate=16 October 2011|year=1999|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=978-90-420-0636-2|page=43}}</ref> }}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox company | name = Fishtank Interactive | logo = Fishtank Interactive.png | type = Publishing Label of [[Ravensburger Interactive]] | fate = Acquired by [[JoWooD Productions]] alongside parent company | founded = early 2000 | defunct = May 2002 | key_people = | industry = [[Video game industry]] | location = [[Ravensburg]], [[Germany]] | parent = [[Ravensburger Spieleverlag]] }} '''Fishtank Interactive''' was a [[Germany|German]] publishing label and was a division of [[Ravensburger Spieleverlag]]'s [[Ravensburger Interactive]]. It was founded in 2000 to try to expand the horizons of Ravensburger Spieleverlag by publishing more mature games than the rest of the mostly pre-school oriented games of the company, without sullying its reputation. Its releases were usually action games, or [[real-time strategies]], and were known for low production values highlighted by the lack of important features like [[multi-player]] playability. The division alongside its parent were sold in May 2002 to [[JoWooD Productions]].
==Releases== Fishtank Interactive released the following games for PC:
*[[1914 - The Great War]] *[[AquaNox]] - also released for [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] *[[Archangel (video game)|Archangel]] *[[Beam Breakers]] *[[Car Tycoon]] *[[Etherlords]] *[[Evil Islands: Curse of the Lost Soul]] *[[RIM: Battle Planets]] *[[S.W.I.N.E.]]
==Development== Aside from publishing, Fishtank Interactive also developed the game [[Car Tycoon]].
[[Category:Video game companies of Germany]] [[Category:Companies based in Baden-Württemberg]] [[Category:Defunct video game companies]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1911|01|14|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Lodi, New Jersey]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2005|11|29|1911|01|14|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Bayway Isles]], [[St. Petersburg, Florida]], U.S. | occupation = Hotelier, business entrepreneur | spouse = | parents = Francesco Cannova, Catherina Cannova (nee Triolo) | children = Michael (son) | net_worth = }} '''Frank Cannova''' (January 14, 1911 – November 29, 2005) was an American hotelier, businessman and entrepreneur.
==Background== He was born in [[Lodi, New Jersey]]<ref>MY Heritage [https://www.myheritage.com/research/collection-10002/us-social-security-death-index-ssdi?itemId=34988186&action=showRecord Frank S Cannova]</ref><ref>''Tampa Bay Times December 1, 2005 [http://www.sptimes.com/2005/12/01/Southpinellas/Frank_S_Cannova__form.shtml Frank S. Cannova, former board chairman of local bank, dies at 94]</ref> to [[Sicily#Demographics|Sicilian]] parents Francesco and Catherina Cannova. His mothers maiden name was Triolo.<ref>My Heritage [https://www.myheritage.com/names/francesco_cannova Francesco "Frank" Santo CANNOVA, 1911 - 2005]</ref> His father who came to the United States from Sicily at the age of 9, was a millionaire by the time he was 35 years old. Frank Jr. with his family on ten acres of land in New Jersey. His father quit his job as a road contractor at his mothers request and moved to Miami. His father having lost several fortunes including one during the depression was a lesson for Frank Jr., that wealth can be here one day and the next day there's nothing. Frank dropped out of school to work and help the family. When he was 35 he went back to college. He then went to law school and at some stage was assistant attorney general of Florida.<ref>''St. Petersburg Independent'' Monday May 6, 1974 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19740506&id=SdtaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WX0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6501,1817218&hl=ko Section B Never Satisfied Marks This Man - Bethia Caffery]</ref>
He also served in the military during the second world war. In 1968, he moved to [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]] from [[Hollywood, Florida|Hollywood, Fla]].
===Death=== He died on November 29, 2005 at Bayway Isle home at age 94. He was survived by a son Michael and two grandchildren. Also his two sisters Rose and Sally.<ref>''Tampa Bay Times December 1, 2005 [http://www.sptimes.com/2005/12/01/Southpinellas/Frank_S_Cannova__form.shtml Frank S. Cannova, former board chairman of local bank, dies at 94]</ref>
==Business ventures== ===[[Aquatarium (Florida)|Aquatarium]]=== In 1968, he purchased The Aquatarium for 2 million.<ref>Lost Parks [http://lostparks.com/aquatarium.html The Aquatarium AKA Shark World]</ref> Some nine or ten years later, Cannova had a 10 million dollar lawsuit against the city for losses incurred at The Aquatarium after commissioners issued a permit for a water slide then reneged on it.<ref>''St. Petersburg Independent'' September 6, 1978 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19780906&id=QkZQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VlgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5558,1102081&hl=ko 22-A Townhouses May Replace Fish Tanks - Robin Mitchell]</ref><ref>''Gulf Independent'' [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19781221&id=7WFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=31gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6524,1310693&hl=ko Page 3 Cannova One Step Closer To Building - Peggy Rogers]</ref> ===First America Development Corp.=== By 1963, Cannova was president of First America Development Corp.<ref>{{cite web|website=[[Daytona Beach Morning Journal]]|date= April 11, 1963|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers/nid=1873&dat=19630411&id=mn0eAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MsoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2992,1798021&hl=ko |title=Hoffa Linked To $1 Million Loan In Volusia Deal|author= Lee Moore And Mary Bailey}}</ref>
===[[The Hawaiian Inn]]=== In 1974, the corporation he headed took over The Desert Resort. Changing the theme and name, they turned it into a Polynesian one called The Hawaiian Inn. He was the director and major shareholder of Hawaiian Inns of Florida Inc.. His vice-president was Michael R. Triolo.<ref>''St. Petersburg Times'' Wednesday September 11, 1974 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19740911&id=3uklAAAAIBAJ&sjid=THkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4042,75516&hl=ko 13-A Business & Finance, Desert Ranch motel getting new look, name By Ron Yogman]</ref> In January 1975, Cannova had his birthday party held at the Inn with his father, relatives and friends present.<ref>''St. Petersburg Independent'' Saturday, January 18, 1975 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19750118&id=zWdQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QVgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6792,713589&hl=ko House Party ''A Symphony Of Food And Sounds'' - Bethia Caffery]</ref>
Cannova's picture and notes appear on the back of Samoan [[Elvis impersonator]], Fatu Lauoletolo aka [[Mr. Fatu|Mr. Fatu's]] album ''Mr. Fatu Sings Elvis'' with the caption, "Mr. Frank Cannova, The who makes the action happen." The album was recorded at The Hawaiian Inn's Aloha Lounge.<ref>Discogs [http://www.discogs.com/Mr-Fatu-Mr-Fatu-Sings-Elvis/release/5789471 Mr. Fatu* – Mr. Fatu Sings Elvis]</ref><ref>Gigsland [https://www.gigsalad.com/elvis_show_st_petersburg >Elvis Impersonators >St Petersburg Elvis Impersonators >Elvis Show]</ref> In February 1979 as a result of a fire, Cannova sold the inn for around 2 million to [[Resort Inns of America]] which already owned a number of inns in the area.<ref>''St. Petersburg Independent'' February 26, 1979 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19790226&id=oFpQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6FgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2235,2781963&hl=ko Hawaiian Inn Reported Sold]</ref>
===Bank of St. Petersburg=== In 1988, he bought into the Bank of St. Petersburg and had controlling interest of the bank. Prior to the purchase, the bank was under the control of [[Anchor Savings Bank]]. About two years later he was filing a lawsuit against Anchor with claims that he had been misled about the financial status of the Bank of St. Petersburg.<ref>''Biz Journals'' Mar 9, 1998 [http://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/stories/1998/03/09/newscolumn5.html Bank of St. Petersburg set to double office count]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
